More money to train your troops.

You are not strong enough to hold all that weight required with promotion!
Your arms are too weak to advance in the archery ranks at this moment.
You require more horse riding skills to fit your next poisition!
It's your money or your life, {mate/girlie}. No sudden moves or we'll run you through.
Lucky for you, you caught me in a good mood. Give us all your coin and I might just let you live.
This a robbery, eh? I givin' you one chance to hand over everythin' you got, or me and my mates'll kill you. Understand?
we have made very little progress so far
we have succeeded in gaining some ground, but we still have a long way to go
we have become a significant force, and we have an even chance of victory
we are winning the war, but our enemies are still holding on.
we are on the verge of victory. The remaining enemies pose no threat, but we still need to hunt them down.
A squire near the stables in Paris asked you to get his sword from the catacombs. It lies in a tomb in the deep crypts. He will give you 200 denars for the sword.

Michel, a passenger of the boat for Dijon, counted me the situation in France, it belongs to the discreet circle of the rebels, and offered me to be part of it by meeting the rebel leader of a small local group, in the tower in ruins, at the gates of Montpellier.
Go pass the admission test to work as a mercenary for the company of Freelancers. They have a garrison at the Gordaine square of Bourges.
Rebel chief of Montpellier wants to raze a camp near the castle of de Puy. The attack relies on the element of surprise. Rebels troops are waiting for you near the camp.
Rebel chief of Montpellier asked you to intercept a weapons convoy near the village of Rodez. You can take troops from the rebels patrolling near Bourges if you need reinforcements.
You were put in charge of resupplying the starving rebels hiding at {s9}. They ordered a barrel of mead, a unit of bread, cheese and dried meat.
The master of the company of Freelancers told you to reinforce the besieged troops at St. Benezet Bridge in Avignon without bothering to tell who the attackers are. However you have time to go there.
The master of the company of Freelancers orders you to immediately join the battle against Villandrandro robbers at Bourges warehouses.
The master of the company of Freelancers asked you to get rid of a gang of robbers which prowls and does mischief around Bourges.

The master of the company of Freelancers wants you to get rid of an annoying problem. One of his men fled drunk to the Three lilies tavern in the slums of Bourges. He has already slain a city guard in a killing frenzy.

The master of the company of Freelancers gave your first assignment. Patrol the neighbourhoods and talk to the tavern keeper, guild master and merchant (door to the shop at the alley in front of the marketplace), and foreman at the warehouse district. Don't get knocked out if you meet brigands.
Unicorn says he has a job for me and wants to meet at the gardens of Poitiers.
The leader of the rebel camp in the forest of Verzy asked you to lead his men to the Burgundian strongpoint southwest of Dijon. You are to plan an attack and seize the site with the help of rebels.
The leader of the rebel troops hidden in the forest of Verzy sent you to scout the gate of the Germans at Metz and to prepare an operation to seize the food stores.
Unicorn wants you to confess your assassinations to become a Knight at the Jacobin cloister in Toulouse. A letter of recommendation will be presented to the king once this task is performed.

Unicorn sends you out to kill again, he wants you to poison a rich merchant who finances the armies of the Duke of Burgundy. You'd do the deed in his mansion in Reims. Unicorn pays 1000 denars as soon as he learns of the merchant's death.
Unicorn pays 1000 denars if you get rid of the English governor, who is hunting near Senlis. You'll have to improvise because the camp can only be entered unarmed.

Unicorn told you to assassinate important people or general enemies for the good of the cause. You have to get rid of the Count of Caen. Fake an invitation to a banquet, guard the entrance and close in on the Count for a kill.
Rodrigue de Villandrandro asked you to kill a traitor called Mathieu the Spinner. He lives on a farm near Rennes.
Rodrigue de Villandrandro told you to collect his extortion money. Ask for protection money from the armorer, the wholesaler, and the weaponsmith.
Rodrigue de Villandrandro wants you to steal a ring from the vault of an old castle in Tours. Better not get caught because the Kingdom of France will never forgive you.
Rodrigue de Villandrandro wants you to pickpocket a key for him. It's carried by a noble living in the house of the three Sirens in Tours.
The leader of the rebels in Paris asked you to get rid of the English troops stationed in a crypt near the rebel camp.
The leader of the rebels who is hiding in the catacombs of Paris begged you to bring bread and cheese for his starving people.

A wealthy merchant in Rouen offers you 10,000 denars if you can find her daughter. You should start by questioning the tavern keeper of Rouen about the strangers whose table she served on the day of her kidnapping.

A lady called Madeleine in Montpellier asked you to find her husband. She said he was found guilty of treason by the Dauphin Charles of France, and he went into exile in Paris. He is brunette, has a moustache and is called Bernard.
The master of the Guild of Messengers gave you a letter to deliver to the guild master of  Montpellier.
The master of the Guild of Messengers gave you a letter to deliver to the guild master of Marseille.
The master of the Guild of Messengers gave you a letter to deliver to the guild master of Paris.
The master of the Guild of Messengers gave you a letter to deliver to the guild master of Dijon.
The master of the Guild of Messengers gave you a letter to deliver to the guild master of Caen.
The master of the Guild of Messengers sent you to deliver a book shipment to a merchant in the Sainte Catherine quarter of Bordeaux.
The master of the Guild of Messengers told you to take certain items and give them to an armorer in Paris.
The master of the Guild of Messengers wants you to move a shipment to a weaponsmith in Avignon.
The master of the Guild of Messengers gave you a box to transport to a weaponsmith in Reims.
Lost and found : Potion for the Master
You received : Potion for the Master
You are forgiven of your sins by the faction !
I have to repay 3300 denars before it is due, or I risk big trouble.
I have to repay 6600 denars before it is due, or I risk big trouble.
I have to repay 9900 denars before it is due, or I risk big trouble.
I have to repay 15400 denars before it is due, or I risk big trouble.

{playername}, when we started our long walk, few people had the courage to support me. And fewer still would be willing to put their lives at risk for my cause. But you didn't hesitate for a moment in throwing yourself at my enemies. We have gone through a lot together, and there were times I came close to losing all hope. But with God's help, we prevailed. It is now time for me to leave your company and take what's rightfully mine. From now on, I will carry out the great responsibility of ruling {s3}. There still lie many challanges ahead and I count on your help in overcoming those. And of course, you will always remain as my foremost vassal.
Find and speak with {s3} of {s4} to give him your oath of homage.
We will of course need to wait until the realm is no longer on campaign.

The Duke of Brittany asked me to investigate the dealings of his rival Stephen de Penthi√®vre. You have to understand how his irregulars could be prevented from continuing to weaken the economy and the power of the Duke of Brittany.
The Duke of Brittany asked me to investigate the dealings of his rival Etienne de Penthi√®vre, You have to find out why the production at the Duke's mines has stalled.
Joan asked me to find a special sword and bring it back to her. You should search for it at the chapel of St. Catherine of Fierbois, which is located south of Tours.

You have to go see the cup-bearer of the Duke who is at the village inn at the mines near the forest of Lorges to learn more. The inn entrance is defended by a guard, who tells you to kill a suspicious adventurer who keeps asking questions from the miners. The guard offers to let you in if the adventurer is dealt with.

The cup-bearer of the Duke thinks he has discovered how the troops of de Penthi√®vre are moving around the countryside undetected. If this is true you have have fulfilled your mission. Verify his assumption.
Your posse is ready to go down into the tunnels of the mine. Kill every soldier you meet there and most importantly free the miners.

The butler of the Duke told you that a contingent of de Penthi√®vre troops is holding miners hostage inside a mine. On behalf of the Duke you have to gather volunteers, go in through heavily guarded tunnels, search for survivors and free them to restart production at the mine.
The landlord of the village inn at the mines near the forest of Lorges asked you to lift a blockade at the lake gate to allow goods to reach the village. He will give food in return.
A hunter at the inn near the forest of Lorges asked me to find a lost arbalest in the woods. Search the forest for an expensive crossbow.

The captain of the mercenary company Iron Skulls of Brittany sent you to siege the Citadel of Quintin owned by the Count de Penthi√®vre. We must prevent the Count's troops from leaving. Apparently there is an enormous reward for killing him. You want to see if sneaking up on the Count and his family is possible even if it means disobeying the captain.

The captain of the mercenary company Iron Skulls of Brittany gave you a contract to monitor the entrance of a Rennes mansion, whose noble Breton owner has received death threats. You have to be his bodyguard to prevent him being killed (go talk to the Count, then the Residents until someone draws weapons).
The captain of the mercenary company Iron Skulls of Brittany gave you your first contract, intercept bandits who attacked a caravan and killed all the merchants and their escort.
{s13} asked you to gather {reg3} heads of cattle and deliver them back to him.
{s9} wants you to follow his army until further notice.
{s9} asked you to scout {s13}, {s14} and {s15}, then report back.
You are challenging me to a duel? How droll! As you wish, {playername}, it will be good sport to bash your head in.
Very well, I will accept you back into my ranks, if you're ready to swear your solemn oath once more.
A pardon will only be possible if you are willing to cede {s17} to me. Do you agree my terms?
No. There is no chance of peace between us, I am not interested.
We are not at war with anyone.
take more time to gather the army.
You promised to help {s13} claim the throne of {s14}.
What do you say to entering the service of {s9} as a mercenary captain? I have no doubt that you would be up to the task.
{s9} asked you to take a message to {s13}. {s13} was believed to be at {s4} when you were given this quest.
{s9} asked you to take a message to {s13} of {s15}. {s13} was believed to be at {s4} when you were given this quest.
{s11} asked you to escort his {s17} {s13} to {s14}.
{s13} asked you to deal with the bandits who are occupying the village of {s15} and then report back to him.
{s9} asked you to raise {reg1} {s14} and bring them to him.
{s9} asked you to collect taxes from {s3}. He offered to leave you one-fifth of all the money you collect there.
{s9} asked you to hunt down a fugitive named {s4}. He is currently believed to be at {s3}.
{s9} asked you to assassinate a local merchant at {s3}.
{s9} has asked you to meet with a spy in {s13}.

{s11} asked you to follow the spy that will leave {s12}. Be careful not to let the spy see you on the way, or he may get suspicious and turn back. Once the spy meets with his accomplice, you are to capture them and bring them back to {s11}.
{s11} asked you to capture a lord from {s13}, any lord, and then drag your victim back to {s11} for safekeeping.
{s9} asked you to lend your companion {s3} to him for a week.
{s9} asked you to collect the debt of {reg4} denars {s3} owes to him. {s3} was at {s4} when you were given this quest.

{s11} gave you a fake letter to fool {s13} into banishing his vassal {s16}. You are to go near {s14}, give the letter to one of your {s15} and send him into the town as a messenger, believing his orders to be genuine.
{s9} has requested you to bring him {reg1} {s3} as prisoners.
Then take it, with my eternal thanks. You are a noble {man/woman}. I will never forget that you helped me in my time of need.
Forgive me, {playername}, but I must insist you accept it. The money means little to me, and I owe you so much. Here, take it, and let us speak no more of this.
{playername}, what a dear {man/woman} you are, but I will not allow you to refuse this. I owe you far more than I can say, and I am sure you can put this money to far better use than I.
{s11} asked you to rescue her {s17}, {s13}, from {s14} by switching clothes and taking his place in prison.
{s11} asked you to rescue her {s17}, {s13}, from {s14}.
{s11} asked you to deliver a message to {s13}, who is imprisoned at {s14}.
You agreed to challenge {s13} to defend {s11}'s honour.

An old adventurer offered to sell me a story! As incredible as it may seem you accepted his offer. You have to find a map of the secret temples of the order of the Templars to find their treasure. The old adventurer told you that the order of the Freemasons is in search for the gold as well. You'd better be fast. The next clue requires finding the secret manuscript of beliefs and rites of the Templars, hidden in a secret lodge of Benedictine abbey of Micy near Orleans.

An old adventurer offered to sell me a story! As incredible as it may seem you accepted his offer. You have to find a map of the secret temples of the order of the Templars to find their treasure. The old adventurer told you that the order of the Freemasons is in search for the gold as well. You'd better be fast. The next clue requires finding the secret manuscript of beliefs and rites of the Templars, hidden in a secret lodge of Benedictine abbey of Micy near Orleans.

The monk scribe at the library of Orleans helped you to get further on trail of the Templars. You have to investigate a character painted on a wall fresco in the monastery of Orleans. It seems that the painted coat of arms is an old one from Occitania. Ask more from the village elders between Toulouse and Montpellier.
A villager from {s7} begged you to save their village from the bandits that took refuge there.
You chose well, {sir/madam}. My lads know how to keep their word and earn their pay.
Well done, {sir/madam}. Keep the money and wine coming our way, and there's no foe in France you need fear.
We are at your service, {sir/madam}. Point us in the direction of those who need hurting, and we'll do the rest.
The Guild Master of {s13} has asked you to deal with looters in the surrounding countryside.
{s9} of {s3} asked you to deliver {reg5} units of {s6} to the tavern in {s4} in 7 days.
Escort the merchant caravan to the town of {s8}.
Merchant {s9} of {s4} asked you to hunt down the troublesome bandits in the vicinity of the town.

The Guild Master of {s4} gave you {reg12} denars to pay the ransom of a girl kidnapped by bandits. You are to meet the bandits near {s3} and pay them the ransom fee. After that you are to bring the girl back to {s4}.

The Guild Master of {s4} promised you {reg12} denars if you can make sure that {s12} and {s13} no longer pose a threat to a peace settlement between {s15} and {s14}. In order to do that, you must either convince them or make sure they fall captive and remain so until a peace agreement is made.
The Guild Master of {s14} has asked you to deal with a group of bandits terrorising the streets of {s14}. They only come out at night, and only attack lone travellers on the streets.
The Guild Master of {s10} asked you to move a cattle herd to {s13}. You will earn {reg8} denars in return.
The elder of the village of {s9} asked you to patrol the forest of {s9} for poachers as hunting is prohibited for peasants.
The owner of an inn near Rouen asked you to rescue an important customer lost in the forest. He'll freeze to death if you do not find him quickly. The landlord also told you about handsome reward.
A drunk in a tavern told me he had lost his horse in the meadows of Bourges. Maybe the mount wasn't very valuable, but I should go and see. It might still be there.
You have completed your guard duty.
He is not commanding any men at the moment.

The elder of the village of {s13} asked you to train {reg5} peasants to fight against local bandits.
The elder of the village of {s3} asked you to bring them {reg5} heads of cattle.
I can smell a fat purse a mile away. Methinks yours could do with some lightening, eh?

Why, it be another traveller, chance met upon the road! I should warn you, country here's a mite dangerous for a good {fellow/woman} like you. But for a small donation my boys and I'll make sure you get rightways to your destination, eh?
Well well, look at this! You'd best start coughing up some silver, friend, or me and my boys'll have to break you.
There's a toll for passin' through this land, payable to us, so if you don't mind we'll just be collectin' our due from your purse...
Another fool come to throw {him/her}self on my weapon, eh? Fine, let's fight!
We're not afraid of you, {sirrah/wench}. Time to bust some heads!
That was a mistake. Now I'm going to have to make your death long and painful.
Brave words. Let's see you back them up with deeds, cur!
A {s5}? Well... Yes, I suppose it is. What a strange thing to ask.
Eh? No, it most certainly is not a {s5}. I'd start questioning my eyesight if I were you.
{s6} Our {reg4?town:village} and the surrounding lands belong to you of course, my {lord/lady}.
{s6} Our {reg4?town:village} and the surrounding lands belong to {s7} of {s8}.
{reg20?We mostly produce {s5} here:We don't produce much here these days}. If you would like to learn more, you can speak with our {reg4?guildmaster:village elder}. He is nearby, right over there.

Army rotates to face enemy center:

You came into the world a {reg3?daughter:son} of declining nobility, owning only the house in which they lived. However, despite your family's hardships, they afforded you a good education and trained you from childhood for the rigours of aristocracy and life at court.

You were born the {reg3?daughter:son} of travelling merchants, always moving from place to place in search of a profit. Although your parents were wealthier than most and educated you as well as they could, you found little opportunity to make friends on the road, living mostly for the moments when you could sell something to somebody.

As a child, your family scrabbled out a meagre living from your father's wages as a guardsman to the local lord. It was not an easy existence, and you were too poor to get much of an education. You learned mainly how to defend yourself on the streets, with or without a weapon in hand.

You were the {reg3?daughter:son} of a family who lived off the woods, doing whatever they needed to make ends meet. Hunting, woodcutting, making arrows, even a spot of poaching whenever things got tight. Winter was never a good time for your family as the cold took animals and people alike, but you always lived to see another dawn, though your brothers and sisters might not be so fortunate.

You were a child of the steppe, born to a tribe of wandering nomads who lived in great camps throughout the arid grasslands. Like the other tribesmen, your family revered horses above almost everything else, and they taught you how to ride almost before you learned how to walk.

As the {reg3?daughter:son} of a thief, you had very little 'formal' education. Instead you were out on the street, begging until you learned how to cut purses, cutting purses until you learned how to pick locks, all the way through your childhood. Still, these long years made you streetwise and sharp to the secrets of cities and shadowy backways.

As a {reg3?girl:boy} growing out of childhood, you were sent to live in the court of one of the nobles of the land. There, your first lessons were in humility, as you waited upon the lords and ladies of the household. But from their chess games, their gossip, even the poetry of great deeds and courtly love, you quickly began to learn about the adult world of conflict and competition. You also learned from the rough games of the other children, who battered at each other with sticks in imitation of their elders' swords.

As a {reg3?girl:boy} growing out of childhood, you apprenticed with a local craftsman to learn a trade. After years of hard work and study under your new master, he promoted you to journeyman and employed you as a fully paid craftsman for as long as you wished to stay.

As a {reg3?girl:boy} growing out of childhood, you apprenticed to a wealthy merchant, picking up the trade over years of working shops and driving caravans. You soon became adept at the art of buying low, selling high, and leaving the customer thinking they'd got the better deal.

As a {reg3?girl:boy} growing out of childhood, you took to the streets, doing whatever you must to survive. Begging, thieving and working for gangs to earn your bread, you lived from day to day in this violent world, always one step ahead of the law and those who wished you ill.

As a {reg3?girl:boy} growing out of childhood, you rode the great steppes on a horse of your own, learning the ways of the grass and the desert. Although you sometimes went hungry, you became a skilful hunter and pathfinder in this trackless country. Your body too started to harden with muscle as you grew into the life of a nomad {reg3?woman:man}.

Though the distinction felt sudden to you, somewhere along the way you had become a {reg3?woman:man}, and the whole world seemed to change around you. When you were named squire to a noble at court, you practised long hours with weapons, learning how to deal out hard knocks and how to take them, too. You were instructed in your obligations to your lord, and of your duties to those who might one day be your vassals. But in addition to learning the chivalric ideal, you also learned about the less uplifting side -- old warriors' stories of ruthless power politics, of betrayals and usurpations, of men who used guile as well as valor to achieve their aims.

Though the distinction felt sudden to you, somewhere along the way you had become a {s13}, and the whole world seemed to change around you. You joined the tightly-knit circle of women at court, ladies who all did proper ladylike things, the wives and mistresses of noble men as well as maidens who had yet to find a husband. However, even here you found politics at work as the ladies schemed for prominence and fought each other bitterly to catch the eye of whatever unmarried man was in fashion at court. You soon learned ways of turning these situations and goings-on to your advantage. With it came the realisation that you yourself could wield great influence in the world, if only you applied yourself with a little bit of subtlety.

Though the distinction felt sudden to you, somewhere along the way you had become a {s13}, and the whole world seemed to change around you. You set out on your own with nothing except the instrument slung over your back and your own voice. It was a poor existence, with many a hungry night when people failed to appreciate your play, but you managed to survive on your music alone. As the years went by you became adept at playing the drunken crowds in your taverns, and even better at talking anyone out of anything you wanted.

Though the distinction felt sudden to you, somewhere along the way you had become a {reg3?woman:man}, and the whole world seemed to change around you. You found yourself as a student in the university of one of the great cities, where you studied theology, philosophy, and medicine. But not all your lessons were learned in the lecture halls. You may or may not have joined in with your fellows as they roamed the alleys in search of wine, women, and a good fight. However, you certainly were able to observe how a broken jaw is set, or how an angry townsman can be persuaded to set down his club and accept cash compensation for the destruction of his shop.

Though the distinction felt sudden to you, somewhere along the way you had become a {s13}, and the whole world seemed to change around you. Heeding the call of the open road, you travelled from village to village buying and selling what you could. It was not a rich existence, but you became a master at haggling even the most miserly elders into giving you a good price. Soon, you knew, you would be well-placed to start your own trading empire...

Though the distinction felt sudden to you, somewhere along the way you had become a {s13}, and the whole world seemed to change around you. You pursued a career as a smith, crafting items of function and beauty out of simple metal. As time wore on you became a master of your trade, and fine work started to fetch fine prices. With food in your belly and logs on your fire, you could take pride in your work and your growing reputation.

Though the distinction felt sudden to you, somewhere along the way you had become a {s13}, and the whole world seemed to change around you. Dissatisfied with common men's desperate scrabble for coin, you took to your local lord's own forests and decided to help yourself to its bounty, laws be damned. You hunted stags, boars and geese and sold the precious meat under the table. You cut down trees right under the watchmen's noses and turned them into firewood that warmed many freezing homes during winter. All for a few silvers, of course.

Only you know exactly what caused you to give up your old life and become an adventurer. Still, it was not a difficult choice to leave, with the rage burning brightly in your heart. You want vengeance. You want justice. What was done to you cannot be undone, and these debts can only be paid in blood...

Only you know exactly what caused you to give up your old life and become an adventurer. All you can say is that you couldn't bear to stay, not with the memories of those you loved so close and so painful. Perhaps your new life will let you forget, or honour the name that you can no longer bear to speak...

Only you know exactly what caused you to give up your old life and become an adventurer. You're not even sure when your home became a prison, when the familiar became mundane, but your dreams of wandering have taken over your life. Whether you yearn for some faraway place or merely for the open road and the freedom to travel, you could no longer bear to stay in the same place. You simply went and never looked back...

Only you know exactly what caused you to give up your old life and become an adventurer. However, you know you cannot go back. There's nothing to go back to. Whatever home you may have had is gone now, and you must face the fact that you're out in the wide wide world. Alone to sink or swim...

Only you know exactly what caused you to give up your old life and become an adventurer. To everyone else, it's clear that you're now motivated solely by personal gain. You want to be rich, powerful, respected, feared. You want to be the one whom others hurry to obey. You want people to know your name, and tremble whenever it is spoken. You want everything, and you won't let anyone stop you from having it...
